data.title: Sky asset depth
data.body:
source:
desc.setZReadWrite( true, false ); allows a given renderable object to test the depth buffer but not write to it.
mIsSky is a new material definition for skyboxes
void DeferredSkyHLSL::processVert( Vector<ShaderComponent*> &componentList,  (and the glsl equivalent) is a method for inserting code into programatically generated shaders. in this case vertex shaders.

script: isSky tagged materials

script(hlsl/glsl): prefabricated hlsl/glsl files reference for cloudlayer and basicclouds objects

immediate purpose: simply adds a variable

long term impact:
One of the primary differences in a prepass lighting vs a more fully parallel deferred approach is that for the former (stock) methodology, lighting is written to the backbuffer, then diffuse is written on top, while for the latter, lighting information goes in one target, and albedo in another for all intents and purposes in a simultaneous manner, then tied up later.

For stock, the lack of depth for sky assets was a non-issue, since these assets were the first thing written after lighting and before the rest of the diffuse-enabled assets. By providing depth and depth testing, this allows one to sort sky assets behind other renderable objects instead of displaying in front of them.

data.title: banding corrections.
data.body:
script
rendermanager.cs- Like it says at the bottom of the file, PFX_PassthruShader is just that, a bottleneck through which all shaders run. The end result of that is that the lighting buffer, which at a minimum uses 16RBG becomes downsampled and bands. Steps were taken with stock torque to mitigate that, but with linearization incoming, the effect is exacerbated.
script(hlsl/glsl) - the saturate command (clamp in glsl) ensures the results fall into a 0-1 range (you'd get a black circle in the center of the sun otherwise)

source: simplification

immediate purpose - slightly noticeable smoothing of light banding with heavily bright lights in extremely dark environments

long term impact - shuts off a future issue with corrected lighting calculations.

data.title: basiconly lighting subsystem bifurcation flag
data.body:
engine: creates and exposes a basicOnly flag, as well as early outs in relevant spots.

script: the rest of the basicoly denotations from the prior PR

immediate purpose: The basiconly flag referenced in https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/858

long term impact: strictly speaking, this one is only of true beneficial use for deferred shading.

Again, used to denote rendering objects which bypass the higher order lighting subsystems.

data.title: defines a new RenderInstType RIT_DecalRoad;
data.body:
engine:
renderPassManager.h - definition
renderPassManager.cpp - reference string

script (to be included in a secondary PR): \game\core\scripts\client\renderManager.cs will add scripted timing and an additional functionality entry.

immediate purpose: provides a render sorting mechanism specific to decal roads.

long term impact: will also include a basiconly flag used by deferred shading to denote that this will only be rendered using the basic lighting functionality, as opposed to the higher-order advanced lighting mechanisms.

data.title: multiple render target support
data.body:
engine:
gfxD3D9CardProfiler.cpp - detection for independent bit depth render targets (meaning checking to see if a card can support writing to an RGBA8 and an RGBA16 simultaneously, or it it requires setting them to the same size)
matTextureTarget.cpp - additional feedback for failed named texture targets
shaderFeature.cpp - correlates rendertargets with shadergen insertion strings so that hlsls and glsls can reference them to write to simultaneously
gfxGLShader.cpp/ shaderGenGLSL.cpp - activates the GL_ARB_explicit_attrib_location OpenGL extension in order to make use of the layout functionality (url included in-engine for full documentation, but the short version is it turns on the opengl equivalent of MRTs), and fleshes out ShaderGenPrinterGLSL::printPixelShaderOutputStruct/ ShaderGenPrinterGLSL::printPixelShaderCloser so that it operates in a similar manner to the directx side.

immediate purpose: prepwork.

long term impact: will allow shadergen and hand written files to render to send data to multiple render targets from one shader file execution, while providing a lookup mechanism for receipt

TODO: detect older versions of opengl, and utilize the array[] method?

data.title: extended mipmap support
data.body:
engine: mipmap support for cubemaps and reflection render targets
immediate goal: none
long term goal: roughness support
TODO: opengl equivalent

data.title: dynamic cubemap support for tsStatics
data.body:
engine: implements the capacity for tsstatic objects to allow themselves to use the reflector system in order to display runtime generated cubemaps.
script: defines a calibrated reflectordesc that reflects all object types within the space of approximately half stock veiwdistance
usage: cubeReflectorDesc = DefaultCubeDesc placed in a given object-insatnces entry that uses a material with a dynamiccubemap = true; flag.
immediate purpose: consistency of application of materials.
long term impact: tags steps required in order to associate a given runtime generated cubemap with an object-instance. in the future, this is likely to give way to an area-derived cubemap based on the accumulation volume tech developed by Andrew Mac, or a screenspace reflection.

data.title: New Physics doc group
data.body: For #765. Because this makes more sense. TODO: add more classes to the physics group, like the physics abstraction classes, which are currently not in any group.

data.title: Fix console func refactor

milestone.description: This version will focus on processing two of the major outstanding pull requests, James Urquhart's [TorqueScript interpreter improvements](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/81) and Tim Condon's [GUI additions](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/545). Along with that we'll be bringing in lots of other TS-related enhancements, adding unit tests for TS to make sure we don't break your games, and processing even more of the outstanding issue list.

engine: creates and exposes a basicOnly flag, as well as early outs in relevant spots.

immediate purpose: The basiconly flag referenced in https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/850
long term impact: strictly speaking, this one is only of true beneficial use for deferred shading.
Again, used to denote rendering objects which bypass the higher order lighting subsystems.

data.title: Create contributing.md
data.body: Github links contributing files to the pull request page [as described](https://github.com/blog/1184-contributing-guidelines). Add one to explain to people what the branches are for and how to make an issue.

data.title: defines a new RenderInstType RIT_DecalRoad;
data.body:
engine:
renderPassManager.h - definition
renderPassManager.cpp - reference string
script:
\game\core\scripts\client\renderManager.cs - controls the rendering order of object types.
immediate purpose: provides a render sorting mechanism specific to decal roads.
long term impact: includes a basiconly flag used by deferred shading to denote that this will only be rendered using the basic lighting functionality, as opposed to the higher-order advanced lighting mechanisms.

data.title: dxt5-based parallax support
data.body:
from @rextimmy
script (hlsl file):  defines a variant on parallaxOffset for use with dxt5 files, parallaxOffsetDxtnm
engine: when generating shaders, checks the material feature MFT_IsDXTnm to see if it is present in a given material definition. if so, it inserts a codeline into the shader referencing the above mentioned method instead of the former version.
immediate purpose: pretty much what it says on the tin.
long term purpose: @eightyeight brought up http://graphics.cs.brown.edu/games/SteepParallax/ as something we may want to look into. this tags the relevant area as well.

data.title: multiple render target support:
data.body:
engine:
A) detection for independent bit depth render targets (meaning checking to see if a card can support writing to an RGBA8 and an RGBA16 simultaneously, or it it requires setting them to the same value)
B) fleshes out the naming conventions for the getOutputTargetVarName ShaderFeature method.

Note: does touch on https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/issues/790. Will folks want that portion included in this PR, or shall we keep the opengl end to the opengl end?

data.title: cubemap mipmap generation
data.body:
engine: mipmap support for cubemaps
immediate goal: none
long term goal: roughness support

data.title: guiobjectview corrections
data.body:
engine: corrects offsets for the guiobjectview gui element which displays materialized meshes, and exposes it's specialized renderering system to the postfx subsystem.

immediate purpose: corrected display
long term purpose: deferred display.

long term impact: tags steps required in order to associate a given runtime generated cubemap with an object-instance. in the future, this is likely to give way to an area cubemap, or a screenspace reflection.

data.title: Example object with collision
data.body:
Extend RenderMeshExample or add a new example that demonstrates buildConvex, castRay, and somethingSomethingPolyList. See [this thread](http://www.garagegames.com/community/forums/viewthread/139996) and maybe [this page](http://torque3d.wikidot.com/coder:collision-system-overview).

Should this involve entirely new objects, or should the existing example objects be modified?

data.title: Underwater fog/caustics/turbulence effects don't disappear when they should

milestone.description: This version will focus on processing two of the major outstanding pull requests, James Urquhart's [TorqueScript interpreter improvements](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/81) and Tim Condon's [GUI additions](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/545). Along with that we'll be bringing in lots of other TS-related enhancements, adding unit tests for TS to make sure we don't break your games, and processing even more of the outstanding issue list.

data.body:
Originally mentioned in #806. Reproduce this issue by
- Loading a mission with water
- Going underwater so the effects appear
- EITHER
  - Deleting the water object, if it is the only one in the level
  - Exiting the mission and loading another mission - the effects will remain enabled

Problem is caused because WaterObject is responsible for updating the effect, and cannot respond to events appropriately. See [updateUnderwaterEffect](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/blob/eeb97ffa4c4af0854070e28159bf38f1b91b31f7/Engine/source/environment/waterObject.cpp#L1061).

Also, possibly revise the system so the effect name doesn't have to be hardcoded into the source.

data.title: Disable all post effects by default
data.body: Fixes the PostFX defaults part of #806, but not the water effect issues, which are more severe (see #841).

data.title: Some engine fixes
data.body:
Fix initializing return buffer.
Fix possible array overrun.
Remove unneeded double-initialization of the vars.

This is #834 rebased onto the correct branch.

data.title: Some engine fixes
data.body:
Fix initializing return buffer.
Fix possible array overrun.
Remove unneeded double-initialization of the vars.

This is #834 retargeted to `development-3.6`.

data.title: SpawnSphere scopes always
data.body: As per [this comment](http://www.garagegames.com/community/forums/viewthread/139870/1#comment-861892), `SpawnSphere` inherits ScopeAlways from `MissionMarker` when it probably shouldn't. If it's needed for the editor then it should set/clear the flag dynamically.

data.title: Update info in README
data.body: Description of downloads is inaccurate after 3.6.

data.title: This adds support for PhysX with CMake
data.body:
Adds a PhysX module for CMake.
This module currently only works in Windows (I'm not developing in Linux currently).
This module attempts to automatically detect which PhysX SDK you're using (PhysX2 or PhysX3) based on the SDK directory structure. PhysX3 requires rextimmy's PhysX3 stuff.
This module requires my other CMake PR #827

data.title: Some engine fixes.
data.body:
Fix initializing return buffer.
Fix possible array overrun.
Remove unneeded double-initialization of the vars.

data.title: Fix: Null'ed pointer usage, possible access violation.
data.body: This fixes issue #700, replaces #701.
